the entire genocide event, which consisted of both civil war and genocide, from 1960 until 1996. Put into scientific terms, what caused the genocide is the society's "belief of extreme inequality and exclusion, which increases violence” (Kumar, 540). What makes this event even more significant is that according to the thesis in Kumar's definition, the people don't really care about what's going on maximum 50 miles away from them and even when they do, the concept of social inclusion was radical among Guatemala's elite citizens . Actually, the impact of this genocide in Guatemala was "far ranging" because either way it was fought, it resulted in "thousands of deaths, hundreds of thousands more being displaced and the refugion of hundreds of thousands abroad" (Kumar, 541). Despite the fact that the consequences of this genocide are still there by the present day, Guatemala has started to take bigger steps by taking precautionary measures for the future of its youth. Importance Of Genocide In Rwanda

1449 Words | 6 Pages

Genocide and Population Growth in Rwanda In 1994, an estimate of about 1 million Tutsi and Hutu suspected of aiding them were killed in a period of 100 days in Rwanda, East Africa from a Botched coup by a former president who was close to the president who was forced to resigned.
